postsData.name:
Tim Denning
Tim Denning
postsData.content:
The most productive people have high agency.

You don't wait for them to act.

They act in spite of a lack of information because they are high agency and resourceful. They have the mindset more than they have the skills.

They're good at networking more than they are writing company policies. They don't as for permission... they just act and seek forgiveness later.

Become one of these people. Worship action takers. Admire people that move with speed and confidence.

<<<>>>

Image Credit:(follow her)

Am I missing anything?
Add it in the comments.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! High agency is all about taking proactive steps. Let’s embrace action and inspire others to do the same! 🚀 #MindsetMatters

postsData.name:
Jason Gordon
Jason Gordon
postsData.content:
Funny how life works...

Last week I shared my meticulously planned daily schedule - hourly blocks, perfectly organized, everything in its place.

Then one of our team members made a simple observation: "Just do your emails and don't get stuck in the day-to-day stuff."

It clicked. Sometimes we overcomplicate things trying to be "perfect."

So I simplified it all down to:
EMAILS → TASKS → REPEAT

Why? Because:
• Emails generate tasks
• Tasks drive action
• Actions create results
• Results lead to more emails

And the cycle continues... 

The power of crafting the perfect schedule has never worked for me.
The power is in simplicity!

Sometimes the best productivity hack is just focusing on the basics and letting everything else fall into place.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Simplifying your approach can lead to greater clarity and productivity. It’s all about focusing on what truly matters!

postsData.name:
David Lorango
David Lorango
postsData.content:
I don't believe that this is gendered in the way Zuckerberg dubs it - but he does identify what has become toxic, debilitating "niceness" that is the bedrock of what I call San Francissification.

The culture of "niceness" is as obnoxious as a hyper-aggressive culture.

What we need is more honesty, being real - treating others like we would people we care about. We don't sugarcoat our real friends - and we don't treat them like trash either.

Pretty simple. Pretty basic.
postsData.commentAdded: Well said! Cultivating genuine honesty over superficial niceness can truly transform workplace dynamics and relationships.

postsData.name:
Lee Harding
Lee Harding
postsData.content:
"What's in it for me?"

People only leave jobs if the job you're offering them is 'better' than what they have today.

So before you write that next InMail or message to candidates hoping to entice them away from their current role, read it over and ask yourself this simple question:

"Does this tell the reader what's in it for them?"

comments.commentText:
Love this! I can totally relate. Before reaching out to candidates, I always double-check my messages too. It’s so easy to get caught up in the long list of requirements and forget the personal touch. 

Honestly, I think this applies to job descriptions as well. Some of them are so dry or overwhelming, they make me want to cry! A little warmth and clarity can make a huge difference—for both candidates and recruiters.
Tatiana Chesnokova 100% applies to job adverts, social media posts and any type of copy aimed to attract candidates

Over the years, I come to find that to improve outreach you need to have recruiters interested in understanding the job. Much like "hearing and listening", taking a job brief and knowing the job are 2 different things.

Then you can see someone's profile and say:
-They would get a promotion
-They would work with newer tech
-They would x advantage...

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Highlighting value for the candidate is key. It’s all about understanding their needs and aspirations. Great reminder! 🌟

postsData.name:

postsData.content: Sharing this for anyone who feels stuck in a pattern with no way out! Don't give up, keep looking for answers. You may be just one click away from turning things around!
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Sometimes a fresh perspective is all we need. Keep pushing forward, solutions are often closer than we think! 💪✨

postsData.name:
Hudson Hector
Hudson Hector
postsData.content:
Let’s talk about burnout.

It’s not a sign that you’re weak - it’s a sign that you’ve been trying to do too much for too long without rest.

You think you’re proving your dedication, but what you’re really doing is running yourself into the ground.

Here’s the truth:

1. You don’t need to do more - you need to do less of what drains you and more of what fills your cup.

2. Hustling harder isn’t the answer -aligning your energy is.

3. Rest isn’t laziness - it’s a strategy for longevity.

 So today, ask yourself:

> What’s one thing I can say no to, so I can say yes to my health and goals?

> How can I create space for rest without guilt?

Drop ‘REST’ in the comments if you’re ready to prioritize your well-being and let go of burnout culture.

Because the most successful people aren’t the ones who work the hardest - they’re the ones who work the smartest.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Prioritizing rest is essential for sustainable success. Let’s shift our focus to balance and well-being. #REST 💪✨

postsData.name:
Julian Goldie
Julian Goldie
postsData.content: This is a valuable lesson learned. It's so important to prioritize our health and well-being. Sacrificing it for a job, especially with the expectation of recognition that might not come, is never worth it. The point about true responsibility starting with self-care is crucial.

comments.commentText: This is a great reminder that our worth is not determined by our productivity or external achievements, but by our inherent value as human beings, and that prioritizing our health and well-being is an act of self-respect and self-love, allowing us to live a more balanced, fulfilling, and meaningful life,.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Prioritizing health is key to long-term success. Self-care fuels our ability to contribute effectively. Well said!

postsData.name:
Nikki Lang
Nikki Lang
postsData.content:
Some unfiltered thoughts for you on a Saturday morning…

Currently writing this caption between sets at the gym, and damn proud of myself for getting here today.

It hasn’t been easy lately.

I have been letting my non-negotiables become negotiable and well, that’s just not my style.

So we are doubling down on the parts where we show the eff up for ourselves. Cause we deserve it, damnit! And so do our families.

They deserve the best of us, not an overworked, overstimulated, resentful version of ourselves.

So take care of you. Get annoyed, get fed up, then make a different choice.

Cause don’t get it twisted, the choice is yours.

That’s the great thing about life. We get to decide what it looks like.

So what are you choosing for your life today?

-Nik the protector

Ps. Please ignore the white stain on my jacket. It’s driving me just as crazy as it’s driving you!!

comments.commentText: I didn't notice the stain until you mentioned it... but like what is it? Toothpaste?? Paint???
Mahmoud Owies hahaha you guys, I have no idea what it was!!! But I picked it off with my nails. True dry cleaning!  Skyler Birk-Stachon

Ooof - resonating with this at the moment. And a little bit hating that it's just the beginning of a new year and I'm already at that stage. But like you, over time I've learned to pick up on the early signs and put boundaries in place early (like today being a Saturday and me prioritising rest even though there's a mountain of work waiting on me).
Branka Injac Misic yes!!! It’s such an important lesson that often takes years for us to learn…. After multiple episodes of burnout.
Nikki Lang yup! Not my first burnout rodeo, unfortunately

postsData.commentAdded: Love your determination, Nik! It’s inspiring to see you prioritizing self-care. Here’s to making intentional choices for a brighter future! 💪✨

postsData.name:
Yuriy Zaremba
Yuriy Zaremba
postsData.content:
Apollo - you can do better.



Yesterday I wrote a post that created a ton of backlash for me.

It wasn't intended that way. I was just sharing my honest opinion about the subject, but obviously I didn't understand the situation well enough.

LinkedIn community educated me.

This post currently has 250+ comments, half of which is me having quality conversations with people, who were kind enough to share their stories and view of the situation.

What really surprised me is that Apollo seems to have used the conversation for their promotion is a weird way.

- VP at Apollo commented under one of the conversations, shaming me;
- someone shortly commented under their comment, saying how great Apollo is.

Maybe I am totally misreading it and it's all genuine engagement.

If it's now and it's a social marketing play - all I want to say is - Apollo, with your resources and customer base you can do much better.

comments.commentText: Lmfao. 2 posts ago you said you replace Apollo. If you’re going to compete with them and win…go for it…but the “you can do better” victim mentality isn’t gonna win markets.
Cory Bray, ok. As you say. I just wanted to share a broader perspective with you.

postsData.commentAdded: Its great to see constructive discussions fostered by your post! Feedback is vital for growth. Lets hope Apollo takes note and improves.

postsData.name:
Lee Harding
Lee Harding
postsData.content:
NO WAY!!! 

My candidate had a 5 year GAP in his resume. After he interviewed with the client:

The feedback I got from them was very disappointing. "Your applicant presented himself very well and seems qualified, but 5 years OFF is a long time, we can’t take that RISK."

“OFF”? He had taken the “break” to sit on his backside and watch The Office reruns with the occasional a nap. In addition, he was also doom scrolling TikTok. He did not hide this on his resume. He wrote "professional sabbatical to unwind."

AND he explained all of this during the job interview.

“RISK”? This is an excellent candidate who kept his skills up to date. Yet all my client could see was the gap. A gap in employment history should not discount someone’s abilities.

Shouldn't a GAP in employment be expected at some point in one's career? If a candidate has the right skills and attitude to do the job, shouldn’t that be enough?

You see nonsense job and career related posts like this on LinkedIn everyday.

For no-nonsense job and career related content, check out my newsletter by hitting the ‘View My Blog’ link at the top of this post.

comments.commentText:
Wondering why did they invite them for an interview if the 5-year gap was such a deal-breaker for them.
Often people expect stories of service or self-sacrifice like “I was raising my kids” or “I was taking care of my old mother” to be convinced that it was a good enough reason. Self-care and extended Sabbaticals aren’t appreciated in corporate and/or hustle cultures.

Taking 5 years off has no less risks than someone who has a 5-week gap in my opinion.
It shows that the person is self-sufficient and not desperate to take on any role; some employers might feel uncomfortable with that.
It also shows that they have their s%+it together because not many people can financially afford to not work for 5 years.
I also see a person with infinite appetite to work and create and get their hands dirty without carrying old baggage or stress from a previous employer.

Best of luck to your client. If they are persistent and well qualified they will surely find a better match!

postsData.commentAdded: Its disheartening to see talent overlooked due to a gap. Skills and attitude should always take precedence over resume history! 🌟

postsData.name:
Cliff K. Locks
Cliff K. Locks
postsData.content:
Your strength lies in the present moment. 

When you focus on the past, that’s your ego: I did this, I won that.
When you live in the future, that’s your pride: I’ll do this, I’ll achieve that.
But in the present? That’s humility. That’s where true greatness lives.

Being fully present allows you to compete with heart, embrace the journey, and stay grounded.

How will you stay focused on the now today?



Sharing this might help someone refocus their energy today. Thank you for passing it on!

comments.commentText: Such a powerful reminder! Staying present is key to growth and true success. I’m excited to see how embracing this mindset can lead to a more grounded and impactful journey!
comments.userName: Cheryl Patterson, RN, MSN, MBA, PhD

I’m thrilled to hear you’re excited to explore this mindset! What steps or practices are you using to stay grounded and focus on the “now” in your journey? Let’s keep inspiring each other to make the present our greatest strength.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing the present transforms our mindset and fuels genuine progress. Let’s make each moment count! 🌟 #Mindfulness #Growth

postsData.name:
Hanna Larsson
Hanna Larsson
postsData.content:
Living a life with zero autonomy isn’t easy.

Building online changed me and my family's life for the better.

Here's how you can get started:

1 - Start with building a new revenue stream

This is not just for employees, I have loads of business owners reaching out to me every day and asking for advice on how they can build multiple income streams.

 Don’t build a massive business plan.
 Don’t go and buy fancy tools or a beautiful website.
 Don’t spend 6 months on planning.

 Start exactly where you are today.

Identify a couple of things you commit to doing every single day.

Start small.
And iterate forward.

To be able to iterate you need to be out there; trying, testing, experimenting, talking to potential clients, getting feedback….

2 - Invest in the skills you need your skills → so you can build what you want.

The easiest way to go to market today with any product or service is to start with creating and posting content on social media.

Start posting online and provide value to people out there.

→ That’s how you will grow your business.

The creator economy market size is projected to be worth $250 billion and is expected to reach $1,487 billion by 2034.

→ The gatekeepers are GONE.

You're not too late.

The barrier to entry is lower than ever before.

 The world is your market.

Posting content online (building in public) has been the foundation of building multiple 6-figures ($) in my business.

3 - Say no to things that are no longer serving you

You need to remove clutter in order to create clarity.

→ If it’s not a hell yes, it’s a no.

This is how you set yourself up for success.

This can mean:

- saying no to friends
- cutting Netflix
- stop doom scrolling social media
- cutting toxic people from your life

And actively search for people who are doing what you want to do.

4 - Create something you own

- ebooks
- a course
- a product
- a podcast
- a newsletter
- 1:1 services
- done for you services
- ghostwriting services

It’s NOT easy.

But living a life with zero autonomy isn’t easy either.

In fact, it can be a total nightmare.

The hardest part about building autonomy is the start.

The rest?

↓↓

Is all about building your MOMENTUM.

And being relentless about the life you want to build.

That mindset and hunger took me to where I am today.

It's given me:

- freedom
- setting my own rules
- designing the life I want
- more time with my family
- more travel and experience the world together
- working from wherever I want (no, I’m not a digital nomad)

And waking up every day feeling challenged, excited, hungry and at the same time content with life.

I want this for you too.


 I teach people HOW in my free newsletter, join us here:

comments.commentText:
This post is a powerful wake-up call. Autonomy isn’t just about financial freedom—it’s about reclaiming control over how you spend your time and energy. The emphasis on starting small, iterating, and focusing on momentum over perfection is gold. True clarity comes when we strip away what’s holding us back and invest in building something of value. The creator economy truly has leveled the playing field, but the challenge lies in consistency and self-discipline.

What mindset shifts or habits do you think are most critical for someone transitioning from a structured, traditional career to building autonomy through the creator economy?

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely inspiring! Your journey showcases the power of starting small and taking consistent action. Excited to see more from your newsletter! 🚀
